Congrats on the paper! It looks fascinating. I look forward to reading it s=
oon. 


Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Assistant Professor
Computer Science
Univ=
ersity of Wyoming
jeffclune@...
jeffclune.com

On Apr 28, 2014, at 3:4=
7 AM, Sebastian Risi <sebastian.risi@...> wrote:

> 
> Kenneth Stanle=
y and I are pleased to announce our new GECCO paper (to appear), "Guided Se=
lf-Organization in Indirectly Encoded and Evolving Topographic Maps"
> 
> P=
DF: http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/risi_gecco14.pdf
> 
> This paper introdu=
ces the idea that HyperNEAT can be seeded with a lateral inhibitory connect=
ivity pattern, which then allows the weights from the inputs to the hidden =
layer of an ANN to self-organize to form a genuine topographic map of the i=
nput space. The benefit of this new approach is that the initial seed can b=
e evolved further to accelerate the self-organizing process and to bias it =
towards a specific target configuration. An interesting implication is that=
 enabling HyperNEAT to capture this key feature of natural systems might no=
w allow us to evolve architectures resembling deep learning networks, SOMs,=
 or other self-organizing processes that also rely on unsupervised learning=
 processes.
> 
> Abstract: An important phenomenon seen in many areas of bi=
ological brains and recently in deep learning architectures is a process kn=
own as self-organization. For example, in the primary visual cortex, color =
and orientation maps develop based on lateral inhibitory connectivity patte=
rns and Hebbian learning dynamics. These topographic maps, which are found =
in all sensory systems, are thought to be a key factor in enabling abstract=
 cognitive representations. This paper shows for the first time that the Hy=
percube-based NeuroEvolution of Augmenting Topologies (HyperNEAT) method ca=
n be seeded to begin evolution  with such lateral connectivity, enabling ge=
nuine self-organizing dynamics. The proposed approach draws on HyperNEAT's =
ability to generate a pattern of weights across the connectivity of an arti=
ficial neural network (ANN) based on a function of its geometry. Validating=
 this approach, the afferent weights of an ANN self-organize in this paper =
to form a genuine topographic map of the input space for a simple line orie=
ntation task. Most interestingly, this seed can then be evolved further, pr=
oviding a method to guide the self-organization of weights in a specific wa=
y, much as evolution likely guided the self-organizing trajectories of biol=
ogical brains.
> 
> Cheers,
> Sebastian
> 
> --
> Dr. Sebastian Risi
> Assi=
stant Professor 
> IT University of Copenhagen, Room 5D08
> Rued Langgaards=
 Vej 7, 2300 Copenhagen, Denmark
> email: sebastian.risi@..., web: ww=
w.sebastianrisi.com
> mobile: +45-50250355, office: +45-7218-5127
> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_8D1F60CF-7E2E-44C6-898D-D63B59AD22C6

e=3D""><div>On Apr 28, 2014, at 3:47 AM, Sebastian Risi <<a href=3D"mail=
to:sebastian.risi@...">sebastian.risi@...</a>> wrote:</div><=
br class=3D"Apple-interchange-newline"><blockquote type=3D"cite">









=



 
<div style=3D"background-color: #fff;">
<span style=3D"display:none">&=
nbsp;</span>



    <div id=3D"ygrp-text"><div><br class=3D"webkit-block-pl=
aceholder"></div><div dir=3D"ltr">Kenneth Stanley and I are pleased to anno=
unce our new GECCO paper (to appear), "Guided Self-Organization in Indirect=
ly Encoded and Evolving Topographic Maps"<br><br><b>PDF: </b><a href=3D"htt=
p://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/risi_gecco14.pdf">http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/paper=
s/risi_gecco14.pdf</a><br>
<br>This paper introduces the idea that HyperNEA=
T can be seeded with a lateral inhibitory connectivity pattern, which then =
allows the weights from the inputs to the hidden layer of an ANN to se=
lf-organize to form a genuine topographic map of the input space. The =
benefit of this new approach is that the initial seed can be evolved f=
urther to accelerate the self-organizing process and to bias it toward=
s a specific target configuration. An interesting implication is that =
enabling HyperNEAT to capture this key feature of natural systems migh=
t now allow us to evolve architectures resembling deep learning networ=
ks, SOMs, or other self-organizing processes that also rely on unsupervised=
 learning processes.<br>
<br><b>Abstract: </b>An important phenomenon seen =
in many areas of biological brains and recently in deep learning architectu=
res is a process known as self-organization. For example, in the primary vi=
sual cortex, color and orientation maps develop based on lateral inhibitory=
 connectivity patterns and Hebbian learning dynamics. These topographic map=
s, which are found in all sensory systems, are thought to be a key factor i=
n enabling abstract cognitive representations. This paper shows for the fir=
st time that the Hypercube-based NeuroEvolution of Augmenting Topologies (H=
yperNEAT) method can be seeded to begin evolution  with such lateral c=
onnectivity, enabling genuine self-organizing dynamics. The proposed approa=
ch draws on HyperNEAT's ability to generate a pattern of weights across the=
 connectivity of an artificial neural network (ANN) based on a function of =
its geometry. Validating this approach, the afferent weights of an ANN self=
-organize in this paper to form a genuine topographic map of the input spac=
e for a simple line orientation task. Most interestingly, this seed can the=
n be evolved further, providing a method to guide the self-organization of =
weights in a specific way, much as evolution likely guided the self-organiz=
ing trajectories of biological brains.<br>
<br>Cheers,<br>Sebastian<br><br>=
--<br>Dr. Sebastian Risi<br>Assistant Professor <br>IT University of Copenh=
agen, Room 5D08<br>Rued Langgaards Vej 7, 2300 Copenhagen, Denmark<br>email=
: <a href=3D"mailto:sebastian.risi@...">sebastian.risi@...</a>,=
 web: <a href=3D"http://www.sebastianrisi.com/">www.sebastianrisi.com</a><b=
r>
mobile: +45-50250355, office: +45-7218-5127
</div><div><br class=3D"webk=
it-block-placeholder"></div>

    </div>
